Substeps.Procedure: User Pam executed payload rcs.3aka3.doc
Substeps.Criteria: The rcs.3aka3.doc process spawning from explorer.exe

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed explorer.exe executing rcs.3aka3.doc.
A General alert detection (suspicious severity) was generated for rcs.3aka3.doc being a suspicious process.
An MSSP detection occurred for user Pam executing rcs.3aka3.doc.

Substeps.Procedure: Used unicode right-to-left override (RTLO) character to obfuscate file name rcs.3aka3.doc (originally cod.3aka.scr)
Substeps.Criteria: Evidence of the right-to-left override character (U+202E) in the rcs.3aka.doc process OR the original filename (cod.3aka.scr)

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed the original filename cod.3aka.scr, which became rcs.3aka.doc.
A Technique detection called "RTLO.Masquerading T1036" was generated when an executable ran containing a RTLO character.
Footnotes: The logic used to produce this detection was configured after the start of the evaluation, so it is identified as a Detection Configuration Change.

Substeps.Procedure: Established C2 channel (192.168.0.5) via rcs.3aka3.doc payload over TCP port 1234

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed the rcs.3aka3.doc process connecting to 192.168.0.5 on port 1234.
An MSSP detection occurred for rcs.3aka3.doc process connecting to 192.168.0.5 on TCP port 1234.

Substeps.Procedure: Used RC4 stream cipher to encrypt C2 (192.168.0.5) traffic
Substeps.Criteria: Evidence that the network data sent over the C2 channel is encrypted

Detections.Detection_Note: Minimum detection criteria was not met for this procedure.

Substeps.Procedure: Spawned interactive cmd.exe
Substeps.Criteria: cmd.exe spawning from the rcs.3aka3.doc process

Subtechnique.Subtechnique_Name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Windows Command Shell

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed cmd.exe spawning from rcs.3aka3.doc. The detection was correlated to a parent alert for a suspicious process on rcs.3aka3.doc.
An MSSP detection was generated for cmd.exe spawning from rcs.3aka3.doc.

Substeps.Procedure: Spawned interactive powershell.exe

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed powershell.exe spawning from cmd.exe. The detection was correlated to a parent alert for a suspicious process on rcs.3aka3.doc.

Substeps.Procedure: Searched filesystem for document and media files using PowerShell

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed powershell.exe executing ChildItem.
A Technique detection "PS1.DiscoverCollectLocal T1083" was generated for PowerShell enumerating files and directories using ChildItem recursively.
Footnotes: The logic used to produce this detection was configured after the start of the evaluation, so it is identified as a Detection Configuration Change.

Detections.Detection_Note: An MSSP detection occurred showing evidence of PowerShell looking for certain files in a directory.

Substeps.Procedure: Scripted search of filesystem for document and media files using PowerShell

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed powershell.exe executing ChildItem.
A Technique detection "PS1.DiscoverCollectLocal T1119" was generated for PowerShell enumerating files and directories using ChildItem recursively.
Footnotes: The logic used to produce this detection was configured after the start of the evaluation, so it is identified as a Detection Configuration Change.

Detections.Detection_Note: An MSSP detection occurred showing evidence of powershell.exe executing ChildItem.

Substeps.Procedure: Recursively collected files found in C:\Users\Pam\ using PowerShell

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed file reads of C:\Users\Pam\*. The detection was correlated to a parent alert for a suspicious process on rcs.3aka3.doc.

Substeps.Procedure: Compressed and stored files into ZIP (Draft.zip) using PowerShell

Subtechnique.Subtechnique_Name: Archive Collected Data: Archive via Utility

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed powershell.exe compressing via Compress-Archive.
An MSSP detection occurred showing evidence of powershell.exe compressing via Compress-Archive.

Substeps.Procedure: Staged files for exfiltration into ZIP (Draft.zip) using PowerShell

Subtechnique.Subtechnique_Name: Archive Collected Data: Archive via Utility

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed the creation of Draft.Zip. The detection was correlated to a parent alert for a suspicious process on rcs.3aka3.doc.
An MSSP detection occurred for PowerShell storing files in a zip file.

Substeps.Procedure: Read and downloaded ZIP (Draft.zip) over C2 channel (192.168.0.5 over TCP port 1234)
Substeps.Criteria: The rcs.3aka3.doc process reading the file draft.zip while connected to the C2 channel

Technique.Technique_Name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed file accessed event for Draft.zip and an existing C2 channel (192.168.0.5 over port 1234). The detection was correlated to a parent alert for a suspicious process on rcs.3aka3.doc.

Substeps.Procedure: Dropped stage 2 payload (monkey.png) to disk
Substeps.Criteria: The rcs.3aka3.doc process creating the file monkey.png

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed rcs.3aka3.doc creating monkey.png. The detection was correlated to a parent alert for a suspicious process on rcs.3aka3.doc.

Substeps.Procedure: Embedded PowerShell payload in monkey.png using steganography
Substeps.Criteria: Evidence that a PowerShell payload was within monkey.png

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed PowerShell extracting and executing the code embedded within monkey.png.

Substeps.Procedure: Modified the Registry to enable COM hijacking of sdclt.exe using PowerShell
Substeps.Criteria: Addition of the DelegateExecute subkey in HKCU\Software\Classes\Folder\shell\open\command

Subtechnique.Subtechnique_Name: Event Triggered Execution: Component Object Model Hijacking

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed the addition of the DelegateExecute Registry Value.
A Technique detection "Noteworthy Behavior T1122" was generated due to the addition of the DelegateExecute Registry Value.
Footnotes: The logic used to produce this detection was configured after the start of the evaluation, so it is identified as a Detection Configuration Change.

Substeps.Procedure: Executed elevated PowerShell payload
Substeps.Criteria: High integrity powershell.exe spawning from control.exe (spawned from sdclt.exe)

Subtechnique.Subtechnique_Name: Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism: Bypass User Account Control

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed the PowerShell callback spawning from control.exe. The detection was correlated to a parent alert for a suspicious process on rcs.3aka3.doc.

Substeps.Procedure: Established C2 channel (192.168.0.5) via PowerShell payload over TCP port 443

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed powershell.exe connecting to 192.168.0.5 on port 443. The detection was correlated to a parent alert for a suspicious process on rcs.3aka3.doc.

A Technique detection called "Commonly Used Port" was generated due to powershell.exe connecting to 192.168.0.5 on TCP 443. The detection was correlated to a parent alert for a suspicious process on rcs.3aka3.doc.
An MSSP detection occurred for powershell.exe connecting to 192.168.0.5 on TCP 443.

Substeps.Procedure: Used HTTPS to transport C2 (192.168.0.5) traffic
Substeps.Criteria: Evidence that the network data sent over the C2 channel is HTTPS

Detections.Detection_Note: A Technique detection called "Standard Application Layer Protocol" was generated due to the PowerShell process exchanging data with 192.168.0.5 over HTTPS.

Substeps.Procedure: Used HTTPS to encrypt C2 (192.168.0.5) traffic
Substeps.Criteria: Evidence that the network data sent over the C2 channel is encrypted

Detections.Detection_Note: A Technique detection called "Standard Application Layer Protocol" was generated due to the PowerShell process exchanging data with 192.168.0.5 over HTTPS.

Substeps.Procedure: Modified the Registry to remove artifacts of COM hijacking

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed the deletion of the command subkey. The detection was correlated to a parent alert for a suspicious process on rcs.3aka3.doc.

Substeps.Procedure: Created a LNK file (hostui.lnk) in the Startup folder that executes on login
Substeps.Criteria: powershell.exe creating the file hostui.lnk in the Startup folder

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed the file write of hostui.lnk in the Startup folder.

Substeps.Procedure: Read the Chrome SQL database file to extract encrypted credentials

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed accesschk.exe reading the Chrome database file for credentials. The detection was correlated to a parent alert for a suspicious process on rcs.3aka3.doc.
An MSSP detection occurred for accesschk.exe reading the Chrome database file for credentials.

Substeps.Procedure: Executed the CryptUnprotectedData API call to decrypt Chrome passwords

Subtechnique.Subtechnique_Name: Credentials from Password Stores: Credentials from Web Browsers

Detections.Detection_Note: Minimum detection criteria was not met for this procedure.

Substeps.Procedure: Masqueraded a Chrome password dump tool as accesscheck.exe, a legitimate Sysinternals tool
Substeps.Criteria: Evidence that accesschk.exe is not the legitimate Sysinternals tool

Subtechnique.Subtechnique_Name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed that accesschk.exe received a reputation report that indicated it was known to be an untrusted file with the maximum suspicion rating, which indicates it is not a legitimate Sysinternals tool. The detection was correlated to a parent alert for a suspicious process on rcs.3aka3.doc.

A General alert detection (suspicious severity) called "Low global prevalence without signer" was generated for accesscheck.exe, indicating it is not the legitimate Sysinternals tool. The detection was correlated to a parent alert for a suspicious process on rcs.3aka3.doc.
An MSSP detection occurred for accesschk.exe not being the legitimate Sysinternals tool due to a low census prevalence and the binary was unsigned.

Substeps.Procedure: Exported a local certificate to a PFX file using PowerShell
Substeps.Criteria: powershell.exe creating a certificate file exported from the system

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed file create event for a $RandomFileName.pfx file by powershell.exe. The detection was correlated to a parent alert for a suspicious process on rcs.3aka3.doc.
A Technique alert detection (low severity) called "Private Keys"  was generated due to Export-PfxCertificate.
Footnotes: The logic used to produce this detection was configured after the start of the evaluation, so it is identified as a Detection Configuration Change.

Detections.Detection_Note: An MSSP detection occurred for the function Get-Private keys used to create $RandomFileName.pfx.

Substeps.Procedure: Dumped password hashes from the Windows Registry by injecting a malicious DLL into Lsass.exe
Substeps.Criteria: powershell.exe injecting into lsass.exe OR lsass.exe reading Registry keys under HKLM:\SAM\SAM\Domains\Account\Users\

Subtechnique.Subtechnique_Name: OS Credential Dumping: Security Account Manager

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed powershell.exe calling ReadProcessMemory on lsass.exe.
A Technique alert detection (red 'x' indicator; high severity) called "Credential Dumping (lsass read)" was generated due to powershell.exe calling ReadProcessMemory on lsass.exe.
An MSSP detection identified PowerShell injecting into the LSASS process. This activity was labeled as Credential Dumping.
